title: 103_s1854
content: The Act of 1994 is titled the "Patent Term and Publication Reform Act" and includes a section on patent simplification. The definition of the term 'filing date' is clarified in Section 100 of title 35, United States Code. Section 102(e) is amended to specify conditions for patentability regarding novelty and loss of right to patent. Section 119 of title 35, United States Code is amended to allow an application for a patent to have the same effect as if it was filed on the filing date of a previously filed application if certain conditions are met. The filing date of a previously filed application can have the same effect on a new patent application if certain conditions are met, such as filing within one year and containing a specific reference to the previous application. This invention must be disclosed in the specification of the previous application filed in the United States before the new application is filed. Section 120 of title 35, United States Code, allows for the benefit of an earlier filing date in the United States for a new patent application if certain conditions are met. The new application must be filed before the patenting, abandonment, or termination of proceedings on the previously filed application. Section 120 of title 35, United States Code, allows a new patent application to benefit from an earlier filing date if it meets specific conditions, such as containing a specific reference to the previously filed application within fifteen months. The application for patents in the United States must be kept confidential by the Patent and Trademark Office, except after 18 months from the filing date when they become open to public inspection. The Patent and Trademark Office keeps patent applications confidential, but they become open to public inspection after 18 months. The Commissioner must promptly publish each patent application when it is available for public inspection. The Patent and Trademark Office keeps patent applications confidential, but they become open to public inspection after 18 months. Every patent shall contain a short title of the invention and grant the patentee the right to exclude others from making, using, or selling the invention throughout the United States. The grant of a patent includes the right to exclude others from using or selling the invention in the United States, as well as the right to obtain a reasonable royalty from any other person who used the invention before the grant. The grant of a patent gives the right to exclude others from using or selling the invention in the United States. It also allows for obtaining a reasonable royalty from anyone who used the invention before the grant, provided they had knowledge of the published application. This applies to patents granted based on published applications and design patents now have a term longer than fourteen years. The term for patents is extended to seventeen years from the filing date, as determined under section 154(a) of this title. The provisions of this Act and its amendments will take effect 90 days after enactment and will only apply to applications filed on or after that date.
